Series 1/6. Panoramic view of 2 images to unfold on my account. "A Night in the Museum", painting with the light. Dressed in full black attire, with gloves like a Ninja in order to forbid any ghosting image of myself while moving in the room. But I reassure you, it was not as glamourous as the adorable Hitchcock movie To Catch A Thief with Gary Grant and Grace Kelly (@studio54laura who share incredible images of movies stars! ;) No. I had the special agreement from Claude Sint√®s, Director of Arles Antique Museum to do this image. It is a multi exposure composed of 70 pictures stitched together. I mixed flash lights and light-painting techniques. I moved with one sole but powerful flash plugged on a 120/240 AC autonomous battery to walk freely, lighting 33 times the room and the boat. After that, I used my flash pilot lamp (plugged on AC this time) offering a constant lighting intensity and focus very precisely the light direction thanks to a focus accessory called a snoot. I light-painted delicately the boat inch per inch like you would do with a flash light. The process took 5 hours with several tests. In receiving the image the day after, Sadie my Picture Editor rushed with the Art Director to present the result to the Magazine Editor, Chris Johns who decided to change the layout with this image as a panoramic opening in 3 pages fold inside the magazine. It was a bet, I worked hard and didn't stole anything ;) Of course, indulge me if I use this opportunity to thank Chris Jones, Sarah Leen, Director of Photography and following time to time here, thank you so much Sarah, Sadie Quarrier my Picture Editor for that story who was so very patient with my emails in English and my French accent on Skype, Kurt Mutchler, Science Picture Editor who is renewing his trust for a new project this year and Robert Kunzig, a charming Francophile gentleman who wrote the story. Thank you all. In my eyes, National Geographic is the best in the world and you should all subscribe dear ones on ig! :)
Series 2/6. Panoramic view of 2 images to unfold on my account. Caption in the precedent image.

Series 3/6. The 2000 years old Roman Boat story was published in the international English version and its 52 languages editions. Here is the Georgia cover issue. Should we share one day a storytelling mentionning Jason and the Argonauts finding the Golden Fleece in Colchide, the modern Georgia? Well, while traveling in the Caucasus Mountains, I might have found the origins of the mythological legend ;)

Series 4/6. Artwork illustrating the story in the National Geographic magazine, published with the courtesy of the NGM. "The Roman Boat Arles-Rh√¥ne 3 arrives at the quay in its last voyage, laden with building stones from a quarry nearly ten miles north of the town. In the first century A.D., Arles was a booming commercial crossroads. The road from Rome to Spain crossed the Rh√¥ne on a pontoon bridge. Goods hauled upriver from the Mediterranean were transferred at Arles to barges that carried them all over France." ¬©Fernando G. Baptista/NGM STAFF, MESA SHUMACHER ART, Jaime Jones MAP, RYAN Morris/NGM Staff.

Series 5/6. Do you know the movie The Party with Peter Sellers or the work of Jacques Tati, a genius movie Director? Self-derision is in my eyes the best form of humor ;) I sent what I had in mind to Sadie, my Photo Editor for the story, 4 months before the shooting, before the boat reconstruction. Perhaps it was too weird and I am not sure she got my plan :)) I never get lonely actually and can crack me up with myself! ;))

Series 6/6. So here arrives the end of our storytelling, which started beginning of November. It was a lot of work to share with you on ig but photographing this recovery for more than 2 years, Arles-Rh√¥ne 3 becomes forever a part of my own life and I posted it with great pleasure. Also, this ancient boat gave me the opportunity to work with the National Geographic. Well, as I told you 4 months ago, I ran the world over for years to catch its attention. When I lost my dear friend Nicolas while he was starting to make it as a photographer with NatGeo, I found life was such an irony. I gave up my professional ambition and moved to Arles. And the story was there, at a few meters from my window. Waiting since 2000 years... Yes, life is an irony but beautiful also and worth to be lived. And I shared with you several times my fascination to Athena, Goddess of War and Wisdom, Protector of the warriors, the travelers, the artists, the musicians and the craftsmen. Two weeks after the inauguration of the boat, the Arles archaeologists called me (thank you so much Marie, Alain and you Fabrice! ;). The Arles Antiquity museum team had just discovered a Roman Villa nearby, 50 BC, with a mosaic and exceptional painted walls. And what was found on this site 30 years earlier? One marble head, one only. The ancient gods need us to exist... Who do you think this Goddess is? THE END. @thephotosociety

Series 1/5. Arles, France. The last preparations before the inauguration of the Roman boat AR3 are taking place. The Antiquity museum conservation team is installing the dishes and tools owned by the boat crew and conserved inside the boat after the wreck.
